title: Data Protection Commission (Amendment) Bill
summary:
The **Data Protection Commission (Amendment) Bill** fundamentally restructures Ghana's data protection regime by establishing comprehensive regulatory oversight, expanding individual rights, and imposing significant compliance obligations on businesses and government entities. The bill extends Ghana's data protection jurisdiction to **foreign data controllers** who offer services to Ghanaians or monitor their behavior, requiring them to appoint local representatives for large-scale or sensitive data processing ([1](#1-application-of-the-act)). This extraterritorial reach positions Ghana among African nations adopting GDPR-style enforcement approaches.

The bill strengthens the **Data Protection Authority's independence and enforcement powers** ([5](#5-independence-of-the-authority), [6](#6-powers-of-the-authority)), granting it authority to investigate breaches, impose penalties, accredit service providers, and conduct compliance audits ([32](#32-compliance-audit)). The Authority operates with constitutional independence from government interference, though the Minister retains limited policy directive authority ([14](#14-policy-directives)). The governing board includes diverse representation from human rights, communications, and financial sectors ([8](#8-governing-body-of-the-authority)), with mandatory gender representation requiring at least three women members.

**For businesses and organizations**, the bill introduces substantial compliance requirements that will reshape data handling practices:

- **Mandatory registration** for all data controllers before processing any personal data, with annual renewal requirements and compliance reporting ([72](#72-processing-of-personal-data-without-registration-prohibited), [69](#69-renewal-of-registration)). Failure to register within three months incurs fines of 2,000-100,000 penalty units ([75](#75-failure-to-register))
- **Data Protection Officers** must be appointed and certified, with the Authority setting qualification standards ([77](#77-appointment-of-data-protection-officers))
- **72-hour breach notification** to both the Authority and affected individuals, with significant penalties for non-compliance ([46](#46-notification-of-security-compromises))
- **Data Protection Impact Assessments** required before high-risk processing activities, with Authority approval needed if assessments reveal substantial risks ([42](#42-data-protection-impact-assessment))
- **Privacy by design and default** mandates requiring technical and organizational measures to minimize data processing from the outset ([44](#44-data-protection-by-design-and-by-default))

The bill establishes **robust individual rights** that empower Ghanaians with control over their personal data. Citizens gain the **right to access** their data ([49](#49-right-to-access-to-personal-data)), **correct inaccuracies** ([47](#47-correction-of-personal-data)), **request erasure** (right to be forgotten) ([55](#55-right-to-erasure-and-the-right-to-be-forgotten)), and **data portability** to transfer information between service providers ([51](#51-right-to-data-portability)). Individuals can **object to automated decision-making** affecting them significantly ([59](#59-rights-in-relation-to-automated-decision-taking)) and **opt out of direct marketing** and political campaign uses of their data ([57](#57-right-to-prevent-processing-of-personal-data-for-direct-marketing), [58](#58-right-to-control-processing-of-personal-data-for-election-campaign)). The bill explicitly establishes that **individuals own their personal data**, not the organizations that collect it ([41](#41-ownership-of-records)), and provides compensation rights for data mishandling ([53](#53-right-to-compensation)).

**Cross-border data transfers** face significant restrictions that will impact multinational operations. The bill requires data controllers to prioritize **data localization** where feasible ([89](#89-basis-for-cross-border-transfer-of-personal-data)), with certain sensitive categories—including national security information and children's data—prohibited from leaving Ghana without Authority approval. International transfers generally require explicit individual consent and may need Authority authorization, with **Transfer Impact Assessments** mandatory for large-scale processing ([90](#90-safeguards-prior-to-transfer-of-personal-data-out-of-ghana)). These provisions create compliance challenges for cloud services, international data centers, and companies with regional data processing arrangements.

The bill addresses **emerging technologies** including artificial intelligence, requiring transparency in automated decisions, regular audits in critical sectors like healthcare and finance, and data protection impact assessments for services using personal data for personalized experiences ([48](#48-application-of-emerging-technologies)). **Sensitive personal data**—covering children's information, religious beliefs, ethnic origin, health records, and biometric data—receives heightened protection with processing generally prohibited except under specific circumstances like explicit consent or legal requirements ([61](#61-processing-of-special-personal-data-prohibited)). Medical information disclosure faces particular restrictions, with contracts demanding medical data without consent rendered unenforceable ([62](#62-demand-for-medical-information-or-health-records)).

The bill includes **practical exemptions** balancing privacy with legitimate societal needs. Journalists, artists, and writers can process personal data for publications when in the public interest ([94](#94-journalism-literature-and-art)), while researchers gain flexibility for historical and statistical work ([95](#95-research-history-and-statistics)). National security, law enforcement, and tax collection activities receive exemptions from standard restrictions ([91](#91-national-security), [92](#92-crime-and-taxation)), though individuals retain rights to legal action if harmed. The bill prohibits **selling personal data** ([108](#108-prohibition-of-sale-of-personal-data)) and prevents businesses from conditioning services on providing specific personal records unless legally required ([109](#109-conditional-request-for-personal-data-prohibited)).

**Enforcement mechanisms** include substantial penalties, with general violations carrying fines of 50,000-100,000 penalty units ([87](#87-general-penalty)). The Authority can issue enforcement notices requiring corrective actions ([25](#25-enforcement-notice)), suspend or revoke registrations ([71](#71-cancellation-or-suspension-of-registration)), and impose administrative fines payable within 21 days ([86](#86-sanctions-and-penalties)). Data controllers can request reviews of Authority decisions within seven days, with appeals available to the High Court ([88](#88-review-mechanism)). The bill repeals the 2012 Data Protection Act while preserving existing authorizations subject to Authority review ([114](#114-repeals-and-savings), [115](#115-transitional-provisions)).

This legislation positions Ghana as a leader in African data protection but creates significant compliance costs and operational challenges for businesses, particularly regarding registration requirements, cross-border data restrictions, and the 72-hour breach notification timeline. Organizations must invest in data protection infrastructure, personnel, and processes to meet these standards, while individuals gain meaningful control over their personal information with enforceable rights and clear remedies for violations.

description.analysis:
The Data Protection Commission (Amendment) Bill introduces **substantial regulatory barriers** that will significantly constrain digital innovation in Ghana. The mandatory registration system requires all data controllers to register before processing any personal data, with annual renewals and compliance reporting ([72](#72-processing-of-personal-data-without-registration-prohibited), [69](#69-renewal-of-registration)). For startups and digital entrepreneurs operating on limited budgets, these administrative requirements create immediate overhead costs that divert resources from product development and market expansion. The requirement to appoint **certified Data Protection Officers** ([77](#77-appointment-of-data-protection-officers)) adds further personnel costs that may be prohibitive for early-stage ventures, while the **licensing requirement for data protection service providers** ([79](#79-accreditation-of-data-protection-service-providers)) may limit the availability of affordable compliance support services in Ghana's emerging digital ecosystem.

The bill's **"assessable processing" provisions** create particularly problematic delays for innovative digital services. Under [76](#76-assessable-processing), data controllers must wait at least 28 days (potentially extending to 42 days) for Authority approval before launching services that involve novel data processing activities—a timeline fundamentally incompatible with agile development methodologies and rapid iteration cycles that drive digital innovation. The Authority's power to **request assessments** and **cease business operations** immediately upon finding violations ([27](#27-request-for-assessment)) creates existential risk for digital businesses, while the broad grounds for **registration cancellation or suspension** ([71](#71-cancellation-or-suspension-of-registration))—including "failure to adhere to prescribed standards" and "inadequate safeguards"—introduce regulatory uncertainty that may deter both local entrepreneurs and foreign investors from Ghana's digital market.

The **cross-border data transfer restrictions** pose severe challenges for cloud-based services, international collaborations, and integration with global digital platforms. The requirement to "make reasonable efforts to localise data" ([89](#89-basis-for-cross-border-transfer-of-personal-data)) and the prohibition on transferring children's data, biometric data, and health records without Authority approval will impede digital health innovations, edtech platforms, and fintech services that rely on international infrastructure. The mandatory **Transfer Impact Assessments** for large-scale processing ([90](#90-safeguards-prior-to-transfer-of-personal-data-out-of-ghana)) and the Authority's power to "prohibit, suspend or subject the transfer to such conditions" create additional friction for digital businesses seeking to leverage global cloud services, international data centers, or cross-border partnerships. These provisions effectively isolate Ghana's digital economy from the interconnected infrastructure that enables modern innovation, while the threat of **license revocation** for various compliance failures ([85](#85-revocation-of-accreditation)) compounds the regulatory risk facing digital innovators.

The Data Protection Commission (Amendment) Bill delivers **transformative improvements to privacy and data rights** in Ghana, establishing one of Africa's most comprehensive data protection frameworks. The legislation fundamentally rebalances power between individuals and organizations by creating **enforceable individual rights** and imposing **robust accountability obligations** on data controllers and processors.

**Individual Empowerment Through Comprehensive Rights**: The bill establishes an extensive suite of rights that give Ghanaians meaningful control over their personal information. Citizens gain the [**right to access**](#49-right-to-access-to-personal-data) their data with controllers required to respond within 21 days, the [**right to correction**](#47-correction-of-personal-data) of inaccurate information, and the [**right to erasure and to be forgotten**](#55-right-to-erasure-and-the-right-to-be-forgotten) - including removal from public links and copies. The [**right to data portability**](#51-right-to-data-portability) enables individuals to transfer their information between service providers in machine-readable formats, while the [**right to object**](#54-right-to-object-processing-of-personal-data) allows citizens to halt processing activities. Critically, the bill establishes that [**individuals own their personal data**](#41-ownership-of-records), not the organizations collecting it, fundamentally shifting the legal framework from organizational control to individual sovereignty. These rights are backed by the [**right to compensation**](#53-right-to-compensation) for damages from data mishandling and accessible [**complaints mechanisms**](#28-complaints-redress-procedure) through the Authority.

**Protection Against Automated Decision-Making and Marketing Exploitation**: The legislation provides strong safeguards against algorithmic harm and unwanted commercial uses of personal data. Individuals have [**rights against automated decision-making**](#59-rights-in-relation-to-automated-decision-taking) that significantly affects them, requiring human oversight and the ability to contest decisions based solely on automated processing including AI systems, facial recognition, and profiling. The [**right to prevent direct marketing**](#57-right-to-prevent-processing-of-personal-data-for-direct-marketing) requires explicit prior consent before personal data can be used for marketing purposes, with maintained proof of consent for audits. Similarly, the [**right to control election campaign processing**](#58-right-to-control-processing-of-personal-data-for-election-campaign) allows citizens to opt out of having their data used for political purposes. The bill [**prohibits selling personal data**](#108-prohibition-of-sale-of-personal-data) entirely, with violations carrying fines up to 50,000 penalty units, and prevents businesses from [**conditioning services on providing specific personal records**](#109-conditional-request-for-personal-data-prohibited) unless legally required.

**Enhanced Security and Accountability Framework**: The bill imposes comprehensive obligations on organizations that significantly strengthen data protection. Controllers must implement [**appropriate security safeguards**](#38-data-security-safeguards) with technical and organizational measures to prevent unauthorized access, loss, or destruction. The [**72-hour breach notification requirement**](#46-notification-of-security-compromises) ensures rapid disclosure to both the Authority and affected individuals, with substantial penalties (2,000-100,000 penalty units) for non-compliance. Organizations must conduct [**Data Protection Impact Assessments**](#42-data-protection-impact-assessment) before high-risk processing and obtain Authority approval if substantial risks are identified. The [**privacy by design and default**](#44-data-protection-by-design-and-by-default) mandate requires minimizing data processing from the outset, while [**legitimate interest assessments**](#43-legitimate-interest-assessment-in-data-processing) ensure processing serves genuine purposes that don't override individual rights. The [**accountability principle**](#33-accountability) requires lawful, reasonable processing that respects privacy rights and adheres to quality standards.

**Special Protections for Vulnerable Groups and Sensitive Data**: The legislation provides heightened safeguards for categories requiring extra protection. [**Processing of special personal data is generally prohibited**](#61-processing-of-special-personal-data-prohibited) unless explicitly consented to or necessary, covering children's information, religious beliefs, ethnic origin, health records, biometric data, and political opinions. [**Medical information disclosure**](#62-demand-for-medical-information-or-health-records) faces particular restrictions, with contracts demanding medical data without consent rendered unenforceable. The [**application of emerging technologies**](#48-application-of-emerging-technologies) provision requires transparency in AI-driven decisions, regular audits in critical sectors, and mandatory impact assessments for personalized services. [**Cross-border transfer restrictions**](#89-basis-for-cross-border-transfer-of-personal-data) prioritize data localization where feasible, with certain sensitive categories prohibited from leaving Ghana without Authority approval, and [**Transfer Impact Assessments**](#90-safeguards-prior-to-transfer-of-personal-data-out-of-ghana) required for large-scale international processing.

**Independent Oversight and Enforcement**: The bill establishes the Data Protection Authority as an [**independent regulator**](#5-independence-of-the-authority) free from government interference, with [**clear objectives**](#4-object-of-the-authority) to protect privacy, prevent data exploitation, establish processing standards, and regulate the digital economy. The Authority maintains [**confidentiality obligations**](#24-confidentiality-of-information) for information obtained during its work, can conduct [**assessments upon request**](#27-request-for-assessment) from affected individuals, and operates transparent [**complaints procedures**](#28-complaints-redress-procedure) with remedial actions and compensation powers. Importantly, the [**bill binds the State**](#2-application-to-the-state), requiring government departments to register, appoint data protection officers, and comply with the same standards as private entities.

**Balanced Exemptions Preserving Legitimate Interests**: While comprehensive, the bill includes practical exemptions that balance privacy with other societal needs. [**Health, education and social work data**](#93-health-education-and-social-work) receives special handling with disclosure restrictions except where required by law, supporting public health administration and disease control. The [**crime and taxation exemption**](#92-crime-and-taxation) allows processing for crime prevention, prosecution, and tax collection without full disclosure requirements, though individuals retain rights to legal action if harmed. [**Examination scripts**](#102-examination-scripts) are exempt from access provisions. The bill also [**prohibits unauthorized purchase, obtaining or disclosure**](#107-prohibition-to-purchase-obtain-or-disclose-personal-data) of personal data, with penalties up to 20,000 penalty units or two years imprisonment.

The legislation's comprehensive approach—combining strong individual rights, organizational accountability, special protections for vulnerable groups, independent oversight, and balanced exemptions—positions Ghana as a regional leader in data protection while empowering citizens with meaningful control over their personal information in an increasingly digital economy.

The Data Protection Commission (Amendment) Bill creates a **significantly more challenging business environment** in Ghana through comprehensive regulatory oversight, substantial compliance costs, and operational restrictions that will fundamentally reshape how businesses handle data. The legislation introduces **existential regulatory risks** through the Authority's power to immediately halt business operations upon finding any contravention ([27](#27-request-for-assessment)), combined with broad grounds for registration suspension or cancellation ([71](#71-cancellation-or-suspension-of-registration)). These enforcement mechanisms create high-stakes compliance environments where businesses face potential operational shutdown for infractions ranging from "failure to adhere to prescribed standards" to "inadequate safeguards" - criteria that may be subjectively interpreted and create regulatory uncertainty.

**Operational constraints and market entry barriers** significantly increase business costs and complexity. The assessable processing requirements ([76](#76-assessable-processing)) impose mandatory 28-day waiting periods (extendable by 14+ days) before certain data processing activities can commence, directly impacting product launch timelines and business agility, with violations carrying criminal penalties of up to 150,000 penalty units or five years imprisonment. The mandatory licensing regime for data protection service providers ([79](#79-accreditation-of-data-protection-service-providers)) creates a new regulated industry with 50,000 penalty unit fines for unlicensed operations, while license revocation provisions ([85](#85-revocation-of-accreditation)) include broad grounds such as circumstances that "would have prevented the Authority from granting" the license if known earlier. These requirements create substantial compliance infrastructure costs, particularly for small and medium enterprises lacking dedicated compliance resources.

**Cross-border data transfer restrictions** pose severe challenges for multinational operations and technology-dependent businesses. The bill mandates data localization efforts where feasible ([89](#89-basis-for-cross-border-transfer-of-personal-data)), requires individual written consent for international transfers, demands Authority approval for large-scale data transfers, and imposes Transfer Impact Assessments ([90](#90-safeguards-prior-to-transfer-of-personal-data-out-of-ghana)). These provisions fundamentally challenge cloud computing business models, regional data center strategies, and integrated multinational operations, forcing businesses to choose between costly data localization infrastructure, complex consent management systems, or restricted service offerings. The "right to be forgotten" requirements ([55](#55-right-to-erasure-and-the-right-to-be-forgotten)) compound operational complexity by requiring businesses to remove personal data "to the greatest extent possible" from "links, copies, websites, replications" - a technically challenging standard for businesses with distributed systems, backup archives, or third-party data sharing arrangements. While these provisions aim to protect individual privacy rights and establish Ghana as a data protection leader, they collectively create a **high-barrier, high-cost business environment** that may deter investment, disadvantage smaller businesses lacking compliance resources, and create competitive advantages for larger organizations capable of absorbing substantial regulatory compliance costs.

keyConcerns.title: Undefined Data Transfer Approval Blocks Digital Operations
keyConcerns.description: The Authority can **block or condition any cross-border data transfer** based on undefined "compelling legitimate interests" and "real risk" standards, with **no specified approval criteria, timeframes, or appeal mechanisms**. This creates severe uncertainty for cloud computing, SaaS platforms, and multinational tech operations that depend on cross-border data flows. Unlike GDPR's adequacy framework, **every transfer of special personal data requires case-by-case Authority approval**, effectively giving regulators discretionary veto power over digital business models with no procedural safeguards.

keyConcerns.title: Criminal Penalties for Undefined "Assessable Processing"
keyConcerns.description: The Minister can unilaterally define which data processing activities require pre-approval using vague criteria like **"substantial damage"** or **"significantly prejudice privacy rights"** - terms with no objective definition. Organizations that process data without approval face **up to 5 years imprisonment** for what is fundamentally an administrative procedural violation. This creates a dangerous combination: undefined regulatory scope determined by ministerial discretion, backed by criminal sanctions, with no clear standards for what requires approval or how the Authority assesses compliance. Startups and tech companies cannot know whether their processing requires the 28-42 day approval period, creating massive uncertainty that chills innovation and enables selective enforcement.

keyConcerns.title: Business Shutdown Without Due Process Rights
keyConcerns.description: The Authority can **cancel or suspend a data controller's registration**—effectively shutting down their data processing operations—without any requirement to provide **notice, opportunity to be heard, or time to cure violations** before the sanction takes effect. For tech startups and digital businesses, this means facing potential **immediate business termination** for violations ranging from serious security breaches to minor administrative failures like late registration updates, with no procedural safeguards to contest findings or correct problems before suspension. This falls short of **international standards like GDPR** which require notice and hearing before such severe sanctions.

keyConcerns.title: Law Enforcement Exemption Lacks Basic Safeguards
keyConcerns.description: This provision allows authorities to process and disclose personal data for crime prevention or tax collection without standard protections, using only a vague **"likely to prejudice"** standard with no judicial oversight, proportionality requirement, or time limits. Unlike GDPR and Commonwealth frameworks that require **"appropriate safeguards"** and independent review, this creates a massive loophole where citizens cannot know if their data is being accessed, journalists cannot protect sources, and authorities face minimal accountability for invoking exemptions based on speculative rather than demonstrated harm.

keyConcerns.title: Absolute Erasure Right Creates Impossible Compliance Obligations
keyConcerns.description: Section 61(2) grants an **absolute "right to be forgotten" without requiring justification**, while simultaneously making individuals bear all consequences of erasure through the liability shield in Section 61(9). This creates a perverse incentive where data controllers are protected from service disruption liability while individuals face unknown risks. More critically, the provision requires organizations to **manage search engine delisting and control third-party republication** beyond their direct control (61(3-4)), creating impossible compliance obligations with criminal penalties. The **30-day timeline for complex erasures** combined with undefined cost assessment standards creates a compliance trap where organizations must either over-invest in infrastructure or risk both penalties and cost disputes with the Authority.

keyConcerns.title: Undefined "Public Interest" Enables Arbitrary License Revocation
keyConcerns.description: The Authority can revoke any data controller's or service provider's license if it determines continuation is "not in the public interest" - **without defining what "public interest" means** or establishing procedural protections. While other revocation grounds (fraud, criminal conviction, failure to meet requirements) are legitimate, this vague standard allows the Authority to **shut down any data-handling business based on undefined criteria**, with no specified right to notice, hearing, or appeal. For tech companies and startups, this creates **existential uncertainty** - you could lose your license to operate at any time based on an arbitrary determination.

keyConcerns.title: Data Localization Mandate Blocks Cloud Services
keyConcerns.description: The bill requires **mandatory localization** of children's, biometric, health, and genetic data within Ghana, effectively prohibiting standard cloud service models that rely on distributed international data centers. Even with data subject consent, cross-border transfers of these categories require **Authority approval** - a discretionary gatekeeping mechanism with no explicit appeal process. The provision also requires "reasonable efforts" to localize all personal data, creating compliance uncertainty since neither **"reasonable efforts"** nor **"large-scale"** transfers (which trigger Authority approval) are defined. This creates disproportionate barriers for startups and SMEs that cannot afford local infrastructure and must wait for Authority approval for legitimate business operations.

keyConcerns.title: Examination Scripts Completely Exempt from Protection
keyConcerns.description: This provision removes **all data protection rights** for examination scripts, allowing educational institutions to retain sensitive academic performance data indefinitely without consent, security requirements, or breach notification obligations. Students lose the right to access their own exam scripts, correct errors, or seek compensation for unauthorized disclosure. Unlike international standards that permit research exemptions **with appropriate safeguards**, this blanket exemption contradicts the bill's core principle that "personal data belongs to individuals" and creates an unregulated repository for sensitive information that may reveal learning disabilities or cognitive abilities.

keyConcerns.title: Business Shutdown Without Due Process Rights
keyConcerns.description: The Authority can order immediate **"cease business operations"** based on a compliance assessment without giving the data controller any opportunity to be heard, present evidence, or appeal before the shutdown takes effect. This violates fundamental due process principles - businesses can be closed down based on a complaint-triggered investigation without defending themselves first. For startups and tech companies operating on thin margins, even a brief operational suspension can be fatal, while the **lack of procedural safeguards** creates potential for selective enforcement against competitors or politically disfavored companies.

keyConcerns.title: Undefined Licensing Requirement Blocks Data Services Market
keyConcerns.description: The bill requires anyone providing **"data protection services"** to obtain a government license or face fines up to 50,000 penalty units, but never defines what constitutes such services. This undefined scope creates severe uncertainty: Does it apply only to specialized DPO consulting firms, or does it capture cloud providers, cybersecurity firms, IT support, analytics platforms, or any business offering data-related services? The ambiguity creates a **market entry barrier** where service providers cannot determine if they need licensing, while the substantial penalty deters innovation. This represents a significant departure from OECD practice, where licensing is reserved for regulated professions, not general information services.

provisions.title: Application of the Act
provisions.plainLanguage: This law applies to data controllers operating within the country, as well as those outside the country who offer services to people here or monitor their data. Data controllers not based in the country must appoint a local representative if they frequently process large amounts of data, sensitive personal information, or data related to criminal offenses. The law also clarifies who is considered to be established or residing in the country for data protection purposes.

provisions.title: Application to the State
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision extends the data protection law to all government entities, treating each department as responsible for the data they control. Government departments must register with the Data Protection Authority before engaging in transactions that involve processing personal data. Certain routine transactions are exempt, and failure to register does not invalidate contracts but may incur penalties. The law also specifies who is considered the data controller within different branches of government.
provisions.rawText:
2. (1) This Act binds the Republic.

(2)  For  the  purposes  of  this  Act,  each  government  department  shall  be treated as a data controller.

(3) Each government department shall appoint an officer to act as a data protection officer.

(4) Subject to subsection (5), government departments shall not engage in any dealings or transaction with other government departments or any other person that involve the processing of personal data, without a valid certificate of  registration  issued  by  the  Authority,  or  by  a  national  foreign  data protection regulator where that person is not established in the country.

(5)  For  the  purposes  of  this  Act,  the  following  constitutes  dealings  or transactions with a person provided that it involves the processing of personal data:

                      - (a) public-private partnerships under the Public Private Partnership Act, 2020 (Act 1039);

                      - (b) procurement contracts or agreements under the Public Procurement Act, 2003 (Act 663) as amended;

                      - (c) any contract or agreement where the data controller processes large-scale data or special personal data;

                      - (e) any contract or agreement for the provision of a services which is  necessary or incidental to the business or operations of the government department;

                      - (f) any contract or agreement that requires cross-border transfer of data; and

                      - (g) international business and economic transactions.

(6)  For  the  avoidance  of  doubt,  the  routine  procurement  of  goods  and services such as food supplies, office equipment, stationery or administrative materials do not constitute dealings and transactions under this section.

(7) The failure of the government department to comply with subsection (4) shall not invalidate a contract or render a contract illegal and unenforceable.

(8)   A government department who breaches subsection (4) shall be liable to an administrative penalty.

(9)  The  Authority  may  by  guidelines  or  directives,  determine  which categories  of  dealings  or  transactions  under  subsection  (5)  may  be  not  be subject to the requirements under subsection (4) for the time being.

(10) The Minister may by legislative instrument expand the categories or transactions under subsection (5).

(11) Where the purposes and the way the processing of personal data are determined by a person acting on behalf of the Executive, Parliament and the Judiciary, the data controller in respect of that data for the purposes of this Act is

(a) in relation to the Executive, the Chief of Staff,

(b) in relation to Parliament, the Clerk to Parliament, and

(c) in relation to the Judiciary, the Judicial Secretary.

(12)  Despite  subsection  (11),  a  person  in  a  different  capacity  may  be appointed as data controller and such person must be designated in writing to the Authority.

## Data Protection Authority

provisions.title: Establishment of the Data Protection Authority
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision creates the Data Protection Authority as a legally recognized entity. The Authority has the power to enter into legal agreements, manage its own assets, and can acquire property as needed. This establishes the Authority as an independent body with the capacity to operate and fulfill its responsibilities.
provisions.rawText:
- (1) There is established by this Act, the Data Protection Authority.

  - The Authority -

                    - (a) shall  be  a  body  corporate,  with  perpetual  succession  and  a common seal;

                    - (b) may sue or be sued in its corporate name; and

                    - (c) may acquire, hold and dispose of its property.

(3) Where there is hindrance to the acquisition of property, the property may be acquired for the Authority under the Land Act, 2020 (Act 1036) and the costs shall be borne by the Authority.

provisions.title: Object of the Authority
provisions.plainLanguage: The data protection authority aims to safeguard individual privacy by regulating how personal information is handled. It seeks to prevent data misuse, set standards for data processing both locally and internationally, and foster trust in digital services. The authority will also define the procedures for obtaining, storing, using, and sharing personal information.
provisions.rawText:
- The object of the Authority is to:

                    - (a) protect  the  privacy  of  the  individual  and  personal  data  by regulating the processing of personal information,

                    - (b) ensure  efficient  management  of  personal  data  to  prevent  data exploitation and abuse;

                    - (c) establish standards for the processing of data locally and by crossborder transfer mechanisms,

                    - (d) regulate  the  personal  data  digital  economy  to  build  trust  and confidence in the delivery of digital services, and

                    - (e) provide  the  process  to  obtain,  hold,  use  or  disclose  personal information.

provisions.title: Independence of the Authority
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision ensures the Authority operates independently, free from external control or influence, including from the government. The Authority has the main responsibility for making decisions and enforcing the law, protecting individual rights. It must act impartially and fairly. The Authority also controls its own structure and internal processes.
provisions.rawText:
5. (1)  The  Authority  shall  be  independent,  and  shall  not  be  subject  to  the direction, control, influence and pressure of any person or authority, including the government in the exercise of its object, powers and functions.

(2)  The  primary  decision-making power and enforcement as it relates to rights and obligations under this Act shall reside with the Authority.

(4)  The Authority shall establish and implement mechanisms for ensuring accountability of the actions or inactions and obligations of data controllers and data processors under the Act.

(5) The Authority shall have power to determine its organisational structure and regulate its own internal procedures.

provisions.title: Powers of the Authority
provisions.plainLanguage: This section grants the Authority the power to regulate market conduct, investigate data protection breaches, and accredit data protection service providers. It also allows the Authority to help resolve disputes, summon witnesses for investigations, and issue penalties for non-compliance. Finally, the Authority can make any determinations it deems fair and just.

provisions.title: Functions of the Authority
provisions.plainLanguage: The Authority is responsible for ensuring that the Data Protection Act is followed. This includes handling complaints, maintaining a register of data protection information, and conducting audits to check for compliance. The Authority will also provide training for data protection officers and take action to correct any violations of the Act.

provisions.title: Governing body of the Authority
provisions.plainLanguage: This section describes the structure of the Authority's governing board. The board includes representatives from several organizations like the Commission on Human Rights, the Ministry of Communications, and the Bank of Ghana, as well as members appointed by the President and one elected by the Industry Forum. The President appoints all board members, and the board is responsible for making sure the Authority operates effectively. The board must have at least three women as members.

provisions.title: Duties and liabilities of a member of the Board of Directors
provisions.plainLanguage: This section defines the responsibilities and potential legal protections for members of the Board of Directors. Board members must act honestly and in the best interest of the Authority, exercising reasonable care and diligence. They are protected from personal liability if they act in good faith and may be indemnified for legal costs. However, they face fines and may be required to compensate the Authority for losses resulting from breaches of their duties.

              - (c) not to disclose information acquired in the capacity of the member as a member of the Board of Directors to any person or make use of that information, except in the performance of functions;

              - (d) not to abuse the position of the office; and

              - (e) not to pursue personal interests at the expense of the Authority.

(3) A member of the Board of Directors, other than the Director General, shall not participate in the day-to-day running of the Authority.

(4) A member of the Board is not personally liable for damage or  injury to a third party that arises in the execution of an official duty of  that member, if the member at all material times acted in good faith.

(5) The  Authority  shall  indemnify  and  hold  harmless  such  a  member against  any  legal  costs,  including  attorney's  fees,  expenses,  and  liabilities reasonably  incurred  in  connection  with  any  legal  proceedings  instituted against the member in respect of acts done or purported to have been done in the performance of official duties, provided that the member acted in good faith and in the interest of the Authority.

(6) A member of the Board of Directors who contravenes subsection (1) or (2) commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a  fine of not less  than  two  thousand  penalty  units  and  not   more  than  twenty  thousand penalty units.

(7) Where  a  court  determines  that  the  Authority  has  suffered  a  loss  or damage  as  a  result  of  the  act  or  omission  of  a  member  of  the  Board  of Directors, the court may, in addition to imposing a fine, order the member to pay appropriate compensation to the Authority.

provisions.title: Tenure of office of members
provisions.plainLanguage: This section describes how long members can serve on the Board, setting a maximum term of four years with a possibility of reappointment for up to two terms. It allows members to resign and specifies that missing three consecutive meetings without a valid reason results in removal. The President has the power to revoke a member's appointment, and the process for filling vacancies is also outlined.

provisions.plainLanguage: The Board must meet at least once every three months, with the chairperson setting the time and location. A special meeting can be called if at least one-third of the members request it in writing. A quorum of seven members is required to conduct business, and decisions are made by a majority vote, with the chairperson having a tie-breaking vote. provisions.title: Allowances
provisions.plainLanguage: This section states that members of the Board and its committees will be paid allowances. The Minister approves the amount of these allowances. However, the Minister must first consult with the Minister responsible for Finance before setting the allowance amounts.
provisions.rawText: 14. Members of the Board and members of a committee of the Board shall be  paid  the  allowances  approved  by  the  Minister  in  consultation  with  the Minister responsible for Finance.

provisions.title: Policy directives
provisions.plainLanguage: This section allows the Minister to provide written policy guidance to the Authority's Board of Directors, ensuring their work aligns with the Authority's goals. ## Finances of the Authority

provisions.title: Funds of the Authority
provisions.plainLanguage: The Authority's funding comes from several sources. These include money allocated by Parliament, grants and donations received, funds generated internally by the Authority, and any other funds approved by the Minister of Finance. This provision establishes the financial foundation that allows the Authority to operate.

provisions.title: Bank accounts of the Authority
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision requires that all money received by the Authority be deposited into approved bank accounts. The Controller and Accountant-General must approve these accounts. This ensures proper financial oversight and accountability for the Authority's funds.
provisions.rawText: - Moneys for the Authority shall be paid into bank accounts opened for the purpose with the approval of the Controller and Accountant-General.

provisions.title: Expenses of the Authority
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision simply states that the Authority will pay for its own expenses using its own funds. It establishes that the Authority is financially responsible for its operations and that these costs will be covered by the resources it has available. This ensures the Authority is self-sufficient in managing its finances.
provisions.rawText: - The  expenses  of  the  Authority  shall  be  charged  on  the  funds  of  the Authority.

provisions.title: Exemption from tax
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision exempts the Authority from paying taxes, as determined by the Minister responsible for Finance. This exemption is conditional and requires prior approval from Parliament. The exemption is also subject to Article 174 of the Constitution and the Exemptions Act, 2022.

provisions.title: Accounts and audit
provisions.plainLanguage: The Board is required to keep financial records in a format approved by the Auditor-General. These records must be submitted to the Auditor-General for auditing within three months after the end of each financial year. The Auditor-General then has three months to audit the accounts and provide a report to the Minister.

## Enforcement

provisions.title: Enforcement notice
provisions.plainLanguage: This section allows the Authority to issue an "enforcement notice" to data controllers who violate data protection rules. The notice can require the data controller to take specific actions, such as stopping certain data processing, fixing inaccurate data, or informing third parties about corrections. Generally, data controllers don't have to comply with the notice until the appeal period ends, but the Authority can order immediate compliance in exceptional situations.
provisions.rawText:

(1)  Where  the  Authority  is  satisfied  that  a  data  controller  has contravened or is contravening any of the data protection principles, the Authority shall serve the data controller with an enforcement notice to require that data controller to do any of the following: (a) to take or refrain from taking the steps specified within the time stated in the notice, (b) to refrain from processing any personal data or personal data of a description specified in the notice; or (c) to  refrain  from  processing  personal  data  or  personal  data  of  a description specified in the notice for the purposes specified or in the manner specified after the time specified. provisions.title: Cancellation of enforcement notice
provisions.plainLanguage: The Authority can cancel or change an enforcement notice they've issued. This can occur either at the Authority's own initiative or if the person who received the notice requests a change. This provision allows for flexibility in enforcement based on changing circumstances or new information.

provisions.title: Request for assessment
provisions.plainLanguage: Individuals can ask the Authority to evaluate if their personal data is being handled according to the law. The Authority decides whether to conduct the assessment based on factors like the importance of the request and any delays in submitting it. The Authority can publish the report if a fee is paid or waived due to financial hardship. If the Authority finds a violation, it can order the data controller to stop processing data immediately.
provisions.rawText:

(2) On receiving a request, the Authority may make an assessment in the manner that the Authority considers appropriate.

(3) The Authority may consider the following in determining whether an assessment is appropriate:

        - (a) the  extent  to  which  the  request  appears  to  the  Authority  to  raise  a matter of substance;

(5)  Where  the  Authority  finds  that  the  processing  by  a  data  controller  is contrary to the provisions of this Act, the Authority shall issue a determination notice to the data controller specifying the contravention and give  the  data  controller  notice  to  cease  business  operations  and  the  data controller shall comply immediately.

provisions.title: Complaints redress procedure
provisions.plainLanguage: This section allows individuals to file complaints with the Authority if they believe their data rights have been violated. The Authority will investigate complaints, ensuring fairness and transparency, and will allow the accused party to respond. Following the investigation, the Authority will issue a decision, which may include corrective actions, penalties, or compensation. The Authority can also set timelines for the complaint process.

provisions.title: Determination by the Authority
provisions.plainLanguage: This section allows the Authority to issue a written determination if personal data is being handled against the law. This also applies if the data is not being processed for journalistic, literary, or artistic purposes by someone other than the original data controller. The data controller will receive an official notice of this determination.

However, individuals can defend themselves against charges of non-compliance if they can demonstrate they tried their best to follow the original notice.

provisions.title: Compliance audit
provisions.plainLanguage: This section allows the Data Protection Authority to authorize officers to conduct audits to enforce data protection laws. Audits can occur with a warrant, with the data controller/processor's consent, or without a warrant in urgent situations like a data breach. The cost of planned audits is to be agreed upon, and the Authority will review audit findings to determine appropriate actions, such as sanctions or certifications.

## Data Protection Principles

provisions.title: Accountability
provisions.plainLanguage: This section holds data controllers accountable for how they handle personal information. Data must be processed lawfully, respectfully, and for clearly defined purposes. The provision also ensures that data transferred internationally is protected under the relevant laws of the data subject's country or this country, regardless of where the processing takes place.

provisions.title: Lawfulness of Processing
provisions.plainLanguage: Data can only be processed if it's necessary, relevant, and not excessive for its intended purpose, and generally requires explicit consent from the individual. There are exceptions, such as when processing is required by law or for a contract. Individuals have the right to object to the processing of their data, and data should only be kept as long as necessary, after which it must be securely destroyed.

provisions.plainLanguage: This provision mandates that personal data can only be collected for clearly defined and lawful reasons. provisions.title: Quality of Information
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision requires data controllers to maintain high standards for the personal data they process. Specifically, the data must be complete, accurate, up-to-date, and not misleading, relative to why it was collected. This ensures that decisions based on the data are fair and reliable, while also respecting the rights of individuals.

provisions.title: Openness
provisions.plainLanguage: Data collectors must inform individuals about what data is being collected, why it's being collected, and their rights regarding that data. This includes letting people know if providing the data is optional and who will have access to it. There are exceptions to this rule for law enforcement, national security, and certain other situations.

42. (1) A data controller who intends to collect personal data shall ensure that the data subject is aware of

(a) the nature of the data being collected; (b) the name and address of the person responsible for the collection; (c) the purpose for which the data is required for collection; (d) whether  or  not  the  supply  of  the  data  by  the  data  subject  is discretionary or mandatory; (e) the consequences of failure to provide the data; (f) the authorised requirement for the collection of the information or the requirement by law for its collection; (g) the recipients of the data; (h) the nature or category of the data; and (i) the existence of the right of access to and the right to request rectification of the data collected before the collection.

provisions.title: Data security safeguards
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision mandates that data controllers and processors must protect personal data by implementing security measures to prevent loss, damage, unauthorized access, or unlawful processing. They are required to identify risks, establish safeguards, verify their effectiveness, and update them regularly. The provision also requires secure data disposal procedures and tasks the Authority with regulating data protection measures and promoting data protection technologies.
provisions.rawText:
43 . (1) A data controller or processor shall take the necessary steps to secure the integrity of personal data in the possession or control of the data controller or processor through the adoption of appropriate, reasonable, technical and organisational measures to prevent

    - (a) loss of, damage to, or unauthorised destruction; and

                    - (b) unlawful access to or unauthorised processing of personal data.

(2) For the purpose of subsection (1), the data controller shall take reasonable measures to

(a) identify  reasonably  foreseeable  internal  and  external  risks  to personal  data  under  the  possession  or  control  of  the  data  controller  or processor;

(b) establish and maintain appropriate safeguards against the identified risks;

(c) regularly verify that the safeguards  are effectively implemented; and

(d) ensure that the safeguards are continually updated in response to new risks or deficiencies.

(3) A data controller or processor shall observe

(a) generally accepted information security practices and procedures, and

(b) specific industry or professional rules and regulations.

(4)  Data  controllers  who  collect,  process,  or  store  data  shall  implement policies and procedures for the secure disposal of data when it is no longer needed for its intended purpose.

(5) Data disposal procedures shall be designed to ensure the permanent and irretrievable removal of data from all storage devices and systems.

(6) The Authority shall -

(a) regulate  the  deployment  of  technological  and  organisational measures to enhance personal data protection; and

(b) foster the development of personal data protection technologies, in  accordance  with  recognised  international  best  practices  and  applicable international law.

provisions.title: Data subject participation
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision grants individuals the right to access, correct, or delete their personal data held by organizations. Individuals can also request to limit how their data is used. Organizations must respond to these requests within 21 working days.

provisions.title: Retention of records
provisions.plainLanguage: Data controllers must not keep personal data longer than needed, unless required by law, contract, or consent. Data kept for historical, statistical, or research reasons must be protected. Once the retention period ends, data controllers must destroy or delete the data in a way that prevents it from being recovered.
provisions.rawText:
45. (1)  A  data  controller  who  records  personal  data  shall  not  retain  the personal data for a period longer than is necessary to achieve the purpose for which the data was collected and processed unless

                    - (a) the retention of the record is required or authorised by law,

                    - (b) the retention of the record is reasonably necessary for a lawful purpose related to a function or activity,

                    - (c) retention of the record is required by virtue of a contract between the parties to the contract, or

                    - (d) the data subject consents to the retention of the record.

(2) Subsection (1) does not apply to records of personal data retained for

                    - (a) historical,

                    - (b) statistical, or

                    - (c) research purposes.

(3) A person who retains records for historical, statistical or research purposes  shall  ensure  that  the  records  that  contain  the  personal  data  are adequately protected against access or use for unauthorised purposes.

(4) A person who uses a record of the personal data of a data subject to decide about the data subject shall

                    - (a) retain the record for a period required or prescribed by law or a code of conduct, or

                    - (b) where there is no law or code of conduct that provides for the retention period, retain the record for a period which will afford the data subject an opportunity to request access to the record.

(5) A data controller shall destroy or delete a record of personal data or de-identify the record at the expiry of the retention period.

(6) The destruction or deletion of a record of personal data shall be done in a manner that prevents its reconstruction in an intelligible form.

provisions.title: Ownership of records
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision clarifies that your personal data belongs to you, not the companies that collect or process it. These companies are considered custodians of your data and must handle it according to the law and your consent. Owning the computers or databases that store your data does not give a company ownership of the data itself. Any existing laws that conflict with this principle are invalid.
provisions.rawText:
46. (1)  As far as personal data is concerned, personal data shall remain the property of the data subject and shall not be deemed to be owned by any other person or entity solely by virtue of its processing.

(2) A data controller or data processor shall be deemed to be a custodian or steward of personal data and shall only process such data in accordance with this Act and for the purposes explicitly consented to by the data subject or permitted under law.

(3) Any provision of another enactment that purports to confer proprietary rights over personal data to a person other than the data subject shall, to the extent of such inconsistency, be void and of no effect.

(4) For the avoidance of doubt, ownership of computer equipment, databases, or software systems used to store or process personal data shall not confer ownership of the personal data contained therein.

provisions.title: Data Protection Impact Assessment
provisions.plainLanguage: This section mandates that data controllers or processors must conduct a data protection impact assessment before processing personal data if it's likely to pose a risk to individuals. The assessment should evaluate the processing activities, their legal basis, potential risks, and measures to mitigate those risks. If the assessment reveals a high risk, a report must be submitted to the Authority for review and approval before processing can proceed. The Authority will provide guidelines for conducting these assessments.
provisions.rawText:
47. (1) Where a data processing activity is likely to pose real risk to the rights and freedoms of a data subject, the data controller or data processor shall conduct a data protection impact assessment prior to processing the personal data.

(2)    In  consideration  of  the  rights  and  legitimate  interests  of  data subjects, the data protection  impact  assessment  must  encompass  the following elements:

                  - (a) details  of  the  intended  processing  activities,  the  purposes  of  the intended processing activities, and any legitimate interests pursued by the data controller or data processor.

                  - (b) an  evaluation  of  the  legal  basis,  and  appropriateness  of  the processing activities with respect to their intended purposes.

                  - (c) an appraisal of the potential risks posed to the rights and freedoms of data subjects.

                  - (d) the  proposed  measures  to  mitigate  identified  risks,  along  with security  safeguards  aimed  at  ensuring  the  protection  of  personal data  and  demonstrating compliance with the relevant provisions outlined in this Act.

(3)    Should  a  data  protection  impact  assessment  conducted  under  this section reveal that the processing of data would likely result in a real high risk to the rights and freedoms of a data subject, the data controller or data processor is  obligated to submit a report to the Authority for review and approval before proceeding with the processing.

(4) The Authority shall provide comprehensive guidelines for the execution of  impact  assessments  as  outlined  in  this  section,  ensuring  clarity  and consistency in their implementation.

provisions.title: Legitimate interest assessment in data processing
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision requires data controllers to conduct and document a Legitimate Interest Assessment before processing personal data based on legitimate interests. The assessment must evaluate the legitimacy and necessity of the interest, and weigh it against the rights of the individual whose data is being processed. If an individual objects to the processing, the data controller must reassess the LIA and stop processing if the individual's rights override the legitimate interest. The Authority can request access to LIA documentation to ensure compliance.
provisions.rawText:
48. (1) A data controller shall ensure that any processing of personal data based on legitimate interests is preceded by a Legitimate Interest Assessment.

(2) The Legitimate Interest Assessment shall include:

          - (a) a determination that the processing serves a legitimate interest of the data controller or a third party;

          - (b) an evaluation of whether the processing is necessary to achieve the identified interest; and

          - (c) an assessment of whether the legitimate interest outweighs the rights and freedoms of the data subject.

(3) The data controller shall document the Legitimate Interest Assessment and maintain records demonstrating compliance with this section.

(4) Where the data subject objects to processing on grounds relating to their rights and freedoms, the data controller shall reassess the Legitimate Interest Assessment and  cease  processing  where  the  interests  of  the  data  subject override the legitimate interest.

(5) The Authority may  request access to the Legitimate Interest Assessment documentation to verify compliance with this section.

provisions.title: Data protection by design and by default
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision mandates that data handlers must build data protection into their systems from the start and ensure that, by default, they only process the minimum amount of personal data needed. Data controllers and processors must implement technical and organizational measures to protect personal data. The Minister can specify which data controllers and industries must follow these rules.
provisions.rawText:
49. (1) A data controller or data processor shall implement appropriate technical and organisational measures which are designed-

(a) to implement the data protection principles in an effective manner; and

(b) to integrate necessary safeguards for that purpose into the processing.

(2)    The  duty  under  subsection  (1)  applies  both  at  the  time  of  the determination  of  the  means  of  processing  the  data  and  at  the  time  of  the processing.

(3)  A data controller or data processor shall implement appropriate technical and organisational measures for ensuring that, by default, only personal data which  is  necessary  for  each  specific  purpose  is  processed,  taking  into consideration(a) the amount of personal data collected; (b) the extent of its processing; (c) the period of its storage; (d) its accessibility; and (e) the cost of processing data and the technologies and tools used. (4)  To give effect to this section, the data controller or data processor shall consider measures such as (a) to identify reasonably foreseeable internal and external risks to personal data under the person's possession or control; (b) to establish and maintain appropriate safeguards against the identified risks; (c) to the pseudonymization and encryption of personal data; (d) to the ability to restore the availability and access to personal data in a timely manner in the event of a physical or technical incident; (e) to verify that the safeguards are effectively implemented; and (f) to ensure that the safeguards are continually updated in response to new risks or deficiencies.

(5) The Minister shall by legislative instrument specify categories of data controllers  and  industry-specific  data  controllers  that  must  implement  this requirement.

provisions.title: Data processor to comply with security measures
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision mandates that data processors working for data controllers must implement and follow specific security measures to protect personal data. Data controllers must have written contracts with their data processors that require them to maintain data confidentiality and security. If a data processor is located outside of the country, the data controller is responsible for ensuring they comply with the relevant local laws.

provisions.title: Notification of  security compromises
provisions.plainLanguage: If a data controller experiences a security breach that affects personal data, they must notify both the Authority and the individuals whose data was compromised, generally within 72 hours. The data controller must also work to restore the security of the system. Notification to individuals can be delayed if it would hinder a criminal investigation. Failure to report a breach within the required timeframe can result in significant penalties.

provisions.title: Correction of personal data
provisions.plainLanguage: This section allows individuals to ask for their personal data to be corrected or deleted if it's inaccurate, outdated, or unlawfully obtained. The data controller must either comply with the request or provide evidence justifying the data's accuracy. If no agreement is reached, the data controller must note the unresolved request on the record. Individuals are responsible for any negative consequences if deleting their data affects essential services or legal obligations.
provisions.rawText:

provisions.title: Application of Emerging Technologies
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision focuses on regulating the use of emerging technologies in data processing. It requires organizations to protect personal data, ensure transparency in automated decisions, and undergo regular audits, especially in critical sectors like healthcare and finance. Services using personal data for tailored experiences, such as social media and e-commerce, must conduct data protection impact assessments.
provisions.rawText:
53. (1) Data controllers utilising advanced methods in data processing shall ensure compliance with data protection principles.

(2) Technology-driven decisions impacting data subjects shall be explainable, contestable, and subject to human oversight to prevent bias and harm.

(3) Privacy enhancing technologies shall be employed to ensure transparency and accountability in automated decision-making processes. (4) The Authority shall regulate data processing involving these technologies,  conduct  risk  assessments,  and  impose  penalties  for  noncompliance. (5)  Systems  used  in  critical  sectors  including  but  not  limited  to  health, energy, finance, banking, government services, transportation and logistics, food  and  agriculture  shall  undergo  periodic  audits  bi-annually  to  evaluate ethical  implications  and  ensure  adherence  to  national  and  international standards. (6)  Data  controllers  developing  or  deploying  such  technologies  shall implement  safeguards  to  protect  personal  data  from  unauthorised  access, discrimination, and unethical use.

(7)  In  addition  to  any  other  requirements  under an enactment for timebeing, any service that utilises personal data to provide tailored experience,

including  but  not  limited  to  social  media  services;  video-on-demand  or streaming services; messaging application services; and e-commerce services and  relies  on  emerging  technologies,  shall  undergo  a  mandatory  data protection impact assessment prior to launch and shall implement personal data governance frameworks consistent with data protection principles.

## Rights of Data Subjects and Others

provisions.title: Right to access to personal data
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision grants individuals the right to access their personal data held by organizations. Upon request, organizations must provide a description of the data, its purpose, and who it might be shared with. There are some exceptions, such as when disclosing the data would reveal trade secrets or compromise the privacy of another individual.

provisions.title: Right to be informed
provisions.plainLanguage: Individuals have the right to request confirmation from data controllers about whether their personal data is held, to receive a description of that data (including who has accessed it), and to correct any inaccuracies. People can also grant or withdraw consent for their data to be processed, and this consent must be freely given and easily withdrawn. If consent is withdrawn, the data controller must stop processing the data and delete or anonymize it, unless there's a legal reason to keep it.

provisions.title: Right to data portability
provisions.plainLanguage: Individuals have the right to receive their personal data from a data controller in a common electronic format and transfer it to another data controller. This transfer can be done directly between the data controllers. The data controller initiating the transfer is responsible for its security. This right does not apply when processing data for public interest tasks or when it's technically not possible.

provisions.title: Right to complain
provisions.plainLanguage: Individuals have the right to complain to a data controller if they believe their data rights have been violated. The data controller must respond to the complaint within 72 hours. If the individual is not satisfied with the response, they can escalate the complaint to the Authority, which will investigate and may impose penalties.
provisions.rawText:
58. (1) A data subject shall have the right to lodge a complaint with the data controller regarding any alleged violation of their rights under this Act.

(2)  The  data  controller  shall  provide  an  accessible  mechanism  for submitting  complaints  and  shall  respond  within  72  hours  of  receiving  the complaint. (3) Where a data subject is dissatisfied with the response from the data controller or does not receive a response within the prescribed period, the data subject may lodge a complaint with the Authority. (4) The Authority shall investigate complaints and impose penalties where necessary.

provisions.title: Right to compensation
provisions.plainLanguage: Individuals can receive compensation from data controllers if their data is mishandled, leading to damage or distress. Data controllers can defend themselves in court by proving they made efforts to comply with data protection laws. This provision aims to ensure data controllers are accountable for protecting personal data.
provisions.rawText:

provisions.title: Right to object processing of personal data
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision gives individuals the right to object to how their personal data is being used. To do so, they must notify the data controller in writing. The data controller then has three working days to respond, explaining whether they will comply with the request or why they cannot. If an individual's complaint is valid, the Authority can order the data controller to comply with the objection.
provisions.rawText:
